comments.commentBody: Right on.  Let claims be heard in courts instead of terrorism.
This case is about Americans blown up by criminals--not whatever political point you're trying to make.

Israel defeated the combined might of the Arab world in a defensive war. They bought land, fair and square, and then were attacked for it. Your analogy makes no sense, wan and your blase defense of terrorism is creepy. So the old people and children murdered by the Palestinian terrorists were just an "other" that had it coming in your world, huh?

The analogy is totally inaccurate.  Israel (within the 1967 borders)  is a state recognized by the United Nations  The Palestinians refused U.N. recommended partition in 1947 which would have given them a state, albeit a small one.   Furthermore, these attacks were directed against civilians.

Did you read the article? The plaintiffs were not settlers; they were Americans visiting Israel, harmed by the indiscriminate hate of people who would rather take innocents down with themselves than think about what constructive acts they could take to improve their own situation.

The situation in Israel reminds me of old western movies, where American Indians  killed and burned the homes and farms of settlers in a futile attempt  to keep their land. Did these settlers assume some risk when they took land that was inhabited by another people?
Wow skeptic...justifying the murder of an American who was defending homes from illegal destruction. Not a very hopeful cause frankly.

Hi Neal nice try demonizing the victims and shows a lot of respect for the US Judiciary.  Bottoms line, your arguments are like so much passed gas when you hysterically cry war crimes but dont mention Hamas violent agressions (raining thousnads of missiles on Israeli civilians, constructing tunnels underground with the intent of killing civilians).  The innocent civilians who were the plaintiffs here had no missiles, they dug no tunnels, they attacked no one out of hatred and racism like Hamas
Can't wait o see when the award is paid.

Only in America do victims pay the price for defending themselves against massive violence. First the Native Americans then the African Americans and now the Palestinians.

The really sad thing is that this verdict is not a surprise to anyone
Your comment is somewhat incoherent, but you appear to be suggesting that our war on Islamic Jihadists can be settled in courts.  You couldn't possibly be more wrong.

The Palestinians haven't paid their water or electric bill in quite a while.  They've been living on credit.  The development money the West keeps forking over goes straight into the pockets of the PA to pay for rockets and tunnels.  He's right:  money is oxygen for terrorists...  Look at Saudi Arabia's petrodollars.

This had nothing to do with facts or law.

This was decided by the political power of AIPAC and the Likud government over the US political system.

The preponderance of evidence favored the plaintiffs' claim that the named defendants were liable. Generally the potential for such a claim would not be considered a deterrent by political groups with a larger agenda. But in the US, federal tort law (see 42 U.S.C. § 1983) has allowed plaintiffs suffering civil rights violations to seek compensation from such groups as the KKK effectively bankrupting them. And more current law (see 18 U.S. Code § 2333) extends these rights to US citizens who are victims of international terrorism. The PLO can probably avoid incurring monetary loss by withdrawing their funds from institutions linked to the US banking system. Or they can settle out of court and reconsider tactics that potentially endanger US citizens. They cannot avoid liability by claiming their intent was only to harm Israeli citizens.
And just what is your version of what happened in 1948,  aside from the attack of all surrounding Arab nations on Israel the moment she declared itself a state

I wonder what distinctions in the law triggers a valid claim against a 'terrorist' organization but not any against organized and well-financed State terror in the form of declared war?  It seems all the GI's + French, British & Russians - military & civilian - killed in WWI & WWII have a claim against Germany & Japan, no?  If there ever were defendants with deep pockets its those guys.  I'm just saying.

They did try something like that not too long ago and failed.  The court ruled that the IDF was not held solely responsible to what happened to her especially when they had no idea she was in that house to begin with.  It was concluded that she snuck in late at night while an autopsy showed that she was already knocked out by debris falling from the roof.  More importantly, why was she defending a house that was used for weapons smuggling?  Both Corrie and the rest of the International Solidarity Movement should have been arrested for treason in harboring a terrorist organization such as Hamas.  BTW, that group was known for hiding terrorists in their Israeli offices, which is a crime in itself.  Of course, if this was any other terrorist organization, I know a lot who would be demanding that they would be locked up and have the key thrown away or even burned to the stake, but not when it's Hamas or Hezbollah.  Perhaps, Israel should also place on trial the members that helped with the flotilla event as well, which was trying to give weapons to Hamas.

The US and other countries protect citizens travelling abroad for peaceful purposes. That is one reason embassies and consulates exist.
Terrorism is a blot on civilization. It is in the world's interest to take it down. The best and least violent way is to deprive the terrorists of their money. The US legal system has done the world a huge favor.

Everyone who leaves the safety of American territory should accept the responsibility of their own protection and risk. This time it was Israel. What about other nations visited by our nationals? Can they expect American courts to right the wrongs visited on those travelers? This really sets quite an alarming precedent. That's the real story here; that American courts hold dominion over the actions of anyone in the world. The world will view this judgement as the ultimate national arrogance.
Please keep in mind who is actually targeting innocent civilians here compared to who is hitting them only be accident.
Well, the PA is pretty bad, but be careful what you wish for -- Gaza run by an unabashedly genocidal, terrorist organization, for example.
The PA is the same; just cleverer about it.

The PA is pretty good, by the standards of the area.  The alternative is what Congress is being asked to go to war against.  I don't know why you call Hamas 'genocidal'.  Compared to ISIS, they are paragons of reason and human rights.  In any case, both will use this judgement for all it is worth in promoting an islamic led struggle.  If this judgement stands, either it will be paid by Western governments, or the PA will cease to exist because they can't pay their employees.
I am very happy about this. I hope this destroys the PA.

Actually, our forces do commit atrocities against civilians - out of mental anguish or sadism or a mix of a reasons. And we do target civilian areas - you do not seem to know much about the invasions of iraq.
No, because the treaties ending the state of war provided how private claims should be disposed of, and the time has expired.

Let's see if I understand:  It's possible to get a judgement against a non-state terrorist organization for blowing somebody up, but millions of victims of World Wars I & II can't sue Germany and Japan?  What deeper pockets could there be?

"What is troubling here is that the American victims were caught in the middle of a Palestinian-Israeli conflict ..."

Do you know the victims weren't also Israelis? They don't lose their citizenship or benefits when they make their aliyah for themselves, or their decedents even if they never set foot in US.

The 3 x $2.185 million judgment is easily and readily collectible.

Certainly the District Court in Brooklyn can and will order the State of Israel to fork over the $100 million a month that Israel collects as some kind of taxes (as reported by the New York Times) on behalf of the Palestine Liberation Organization and the Palestinian Authority, for 6 or 7 months.

And certainly the State of Israel will obey the Court's order.

Case closed.
I assume you agree that Palestinian civilians should also get their "tort" cases tried in U.S. courts, since the enabling means are entirely funded by U.S. taxpayers.

Part of the problem in talking about Artificial Intelligence is simply the name and all the misconceptions it inspires. Both the term "artificial" and "intelligence" are misleading in the context of computer-based algorithmic decision making to enhance ordinary human activities, such as medical diagnosis, weather prediction, conversation, and so on.

For one thing, there is nothing artificial about a computer hardware+software complex that is capable of making trillion calculations per second, and producing outputs that for intents and purposes, rival and exceed the decisions of ordinary human beings. Acting on those decisions can produce "real" results, so we should stop calling it "artificial."

As to "intelligence," we are not even sure what human, or even animal intelligence is, how to measure it, and how to use it. We traditionally describe the peak of human intelligence as "genius" without really knowing what that means. The idea that the standard IQ test measures intelligence is a joke; at best it measures only a small fraction of the total repertory of the normal, healthy, human brain. If having an IQ of say, 185 means that one can discover the laws of general relativity, we would have had thousands of Einsteins. But so far we only have one. Therefore, IQ alone could not define Einstein's genius.

OK, I have not offered anything to answer the question of this article, but at least I wanted to clear up something about the misbegotten name of this field.

"Biological infestation of our planer"?  I don't pretend to know what the purpose of our planet is if it has any but it seems that life, in all its forms, is an ineluctable concomitant of the evolution of the planet through time and no more an "infestation" than, say, the presence of inorganic compounds.

As a programmer with more than 30 years of experience, I am at something of a loss to understand how non-programmers presume to think they understand computers in general and AI in particular. Program design begins with an objective, a desired function for a computer. I infer from this fact that AI is always the projection of human objectives onto the hardware. The means may be very abstruse, but the goal is always human. Example: Over the years, sort algorithms have become remarkably quick and clever but the goal is always to order data. Limited space suggests we leave additional examples to the knowledgeable and interested reader.

Loose palaver about machine consciousness and heuristics are the stuff of science fiction and marketing, not computer science and expostulations about science fiction often becoming reality are foolish.

As Mr. Bratton rightly points out, the critical issue, not only of our time but of all the history of our species, is the possibility that the human race is the bringer of the Sixth Great Extinction. We do not seem to be able to control our behavior as a species, even when many of us can see that our blood lust and greed have brought us to the edge of another great cleansing of the biological infestation of our planet.
Skip the healthy whole grains and you will do even better.

In reducing the fat in the diet, you've got to increase the carbs, or caloric intake will drop below a sustainable level. In head-to-head studies comparing high-carb-low-fat vs highish-fat-modest carb diets for diabetics, the modest carb diets always do better. I get that it's working for you, and that's great, but maybe try easing up a little on the restriction of the macronutrient that there is zero evidence of worsening diabetes (or heart disease), and edge down on the one that is unquestionably linked with diabetes. A month later if it's still working, wiggle another notch over. You are likely to be a statistically normal diabetic, who will do better on a diet that keeps carbs in checks and fills out calories with metabolically harmless fats.

My diet has been closer to what "science says so" since I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in August, 2011: Less fat, less sweets and junk food, more vegetables (I used to have them once a week), more whole grains.  I'm 20 pounds lighter than I was when I was diagnosed, and I've been taken off many of the prescriptions I was put on, including ones for blood sugar, because of how well I've done with diet and exercise.  And my cholesterol has been improved; that is also worsened by diabetes. I'll stick with what has worked so far, even if it doesn't fit the study du jour.
Like honesty? Personal responsibility? Journalistic Ethics?
Yawn.  The current environment of attack, tear down and smear continues...   Let's all try to focus on what matters in this world, eh
